intro: Aquilegia micrantha var. loriae, commonly known as the Loria's columbine, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is characterized by its striking blue to purple spurred flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with basal leaves that are doubly pinnate and finely divided. Its flowers are composed of five sepals that are modified into petals, with two elongated, spurred petals at the back. This variety is often found in moist, well-drained soils in forested or rocky habitats.
